awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Network Science for All: Positioning Underserved Youth for Success in Pursuing STEM Pathways
awd_abstract_narration:
Boston University, in partnership with Sociedad Latina, will investigate the role that a middle school network science curriculum plays as both an input and outcome of science learning. This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program, which supports projects that build understandings of practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to increasing students' knowledge and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and information and communication technology (ICT) careers. The project team will focus on development of skills to investigate real-world problems that have meaningful consequences for humankind across social, technical, and scientific domains. This project will make use of publicly available data to allow students to be involved in project-based activities in and out of their classrooms that can have societal impact. The project team will leverage previously developed data-driven curriculum in the context of a network science lens, synthesize highly promising technical and STEM resources as well as in-school and out-of-school programs, and embed new education research advances on effective career development to evolve a construct that will best position underserved youth for future learning of science. The curriculum and career development resources will directly reach 600 principally Latinx students, 12 teachers, parents, and other key stakeholders. Project activities will be implemented in a range of in-school and after-school programs in Boston. Through a collective impact approach, the project will be replicable, scale to more schools throughout Massachusetts, inform related projects, and evolve to regional and national impact. 

The project will create novel learning opportunities for middle school students to explore real-world project-based problems addressed through data analysis, data visualization and network modeling. This study will advance the field of interdisciplinary teaching and learning as well as strategies for supporting students and teachers through three interdependent strands: (1) Network Science for All workforce readiness curriculum modules, (2) applied evaluation metrics based on comparing students to peer groups through statewide data, and (3) sustainability and scalability embedded in the structure of the program. The project will be informed by several advisory boards aimed at leveraging the program in order to sustain and scale the effort. At Boston University, an internal advisory board will embed the project into the broad ecosystem of the university as part of a collective impact culture. A STEM advisory board will inform the science program. A formal independent external advisory board will guide the project’s efforts. Research will be conducted in two phases. In Phase 1, design-based research will be used to iteratively refine curriculum and programmatic interventions. In Phase 2, the research will examine the degree to which the program positions youth for success by examining the (1) varied acquisition of next generation STEM competencies for future workforce needs, (2) motivation and engagement of students and their support systems, and (3) impact on shifting STEM-related career goals and pathways to achieving these goals. All materials will be available in electronic forms on a Boston University project website, will be licensed under open-source code and open content licenses, and will be freely distributed to teachers, curriculum developers, and researchers. Research findings will be widely disseminated through publications and conference proceedings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project developed and implemented an innovative middle school curriculum that integrates network science concepts with personalized career development resources. The goal was to enable Latinx youth to develop network thinking, explore STEM careers aligned with network science competencies, establish STEM career goals, and self-determine pathways for future science learning.

Intellectual Merit: The project made several key contributions to advance knowledge in STEM education and career development for underserved youth:

  1. Curriculum Development: We created and iteratively refined 25 interactive network science lessons organized into four modules: Introduction to Networks, Foundational Science, Connections to Health & Human Body, and Synthesis of Concepts. These lessons made connections between physics, biology, and chemistry through a network science lens, broadening students' understanding of science applications.

  2. Career Development Integration: We designed career development lessons that enabled youth to explore STEM careers aligned with network science competencies. Lessons like "Who Am I" and "Cultural Identity" helped students identify their skills, interests, and cultural assets in relation to STEM pathways.

  3. Evaluation Methods: We developed innovative evaluation approaches using comic strips and photo novellas to engage youth in meaningful reflection on their career identities. This provided rich qualitative data on how students' STEM career perceptions evolved.

  4. Empirical Findings: Quantitative analyses of pre-post surveys demonstrated statistically significant increases in students' STEM learning self-efficacy and career exploration self-efficacy after participating in the curriculum. This provides evidence for the effectiveness of integrating network science and career development for underserved middle school youth.

Broader Impacts: The project had several broader impacts on STEM education access, educator capacity, and equity in STEM pathways.

  1. Expanding STEM Access: By partnering with Sociedad Latina/BU and establishing new relationships with West End House and Bikes Not Bombs, we provided high-quality STEM and career programming to over 200 BIPOC middle school students who are underrepresented in STEM education and career pathways. 

  2. Building Educator Capacity: We provided professional development on the curriculum to educators at the three partnering community organizations, as well as those at Boston Public Schools. The educators were provided with administrative guides, lesson slides, demo videos, and access to our research team for additional support. 

  3. Promoting Student-Led Community Projects: Students applied their learning to create public service announcements and photo novellas addressing community issues and needs. This connected STEM concepts to civic engagement. For example, students developed a video PSA about COVID-19 vaccines, leveraging their understanding of network science to explain virus spread and the importance of vaccination. This project allowed students to translate complex scientific concepts into accessible public health messages.

  4. Disseminating Innovative Practices: Over the course of the 4-year project, we actively shared our curriculum, evaluation methods, and findings through numerous academic and professional channels. This included: 2 published journal articles, 1 book chapter, 24 conference presentations at international, national, and regional conferences, and multiple professional development sessions and workshops. 

  5. Sustainable Partnerships: Within Boston University, we formed a team that bridged the Wheelock College of Education and Human Development, the Department of Physics, and the Office of Government and Community Affairs. This interdisciplinary approach ensured a holistic integration of network science, education, and community engagement. We also forged strong relationships between Boston University and two additional community organizations (West End House and Bikes Not Bombs) and strengthened our partnerships with Boston Public Schools to expand STEM pathways for youth beyond the project's duration. 

  6. Advancing Equity in STEM: By introducing students to Latinx STEM professionals and role models, we helped youth envision themselves in STEM careers, countering the underrepresentation of Latinx individuals in these fields. We also provided bilingual materials and support, ensuring that English language learners could fully engage with complex STEM concepts. Lastly, our focus on transferable skills like critical thinking, collaboration, and communication empowered students with competencies valuable across various career paths, expanding their options within and beyond traditional STEM fields.

In conclusion, this project developed an innovative, evidence-based approach to integrating network science and career development for middle school students. By connecting STEM concepts to students' identities, interests, and communities, we increased engagement and self-efficacy in STEM learning, aspiration, and career readiness. The curriculum and partnerships established provide a foundation for expanding access to STEM pathways for underrepresented youth and diversifying the STEM pipeline.


 


Last Modified: 06/27/2024
Modified by: Alexandra Oliver-Davila

This collaborative research project developed and implemented an innovative middle school curriculum that integrates network science concepts with personalized career development resources. The goal was to enable Latinx youth to develop network thinking, explore STEM careers aligned with network science competencies, establish STEM career goals, and self-determine pathways for future science learning.


Intellectual Merit: The project made several key contributions to advance knowledge in STEM education and career development for underserved youth:




Curriculum Development: We created and iteratively refined 25 interactive network science lessons organized into four modules: Introduction to Networks, Foundational Science, Connections to Health & Human Body, and Synthesis of Concepts. These lessons made connections between physics, biology, and chemistry through a network science lens, broadening students' understanding of science applications.




Career Development Integration: We designed career development lessons that enabled youth to explore STEM careers aligned with network science competencies. Lessons like "Who Am I" and "Cultural Identity" helped students identify their skills, interests, and cultural assets in relation to STEM pathways.




Evaluation Methods: We developed innovative evaluation approaches using comic strips and photo novellas to engage youth in meaningful reflection on their career identities. This provided rich qualitative data on how students' STEM career perceptions evolved.




Empirical Findings: Quantitative analyses of pre-post surveys demonstrated statistically significant increases in students' STEM learning self-efficacy and career exploration self-efficacy after participating in the curriculum. This provides evidence for the effectiveness of integrating network science and career development for underserved middle school youth.




Broader Impacts: The project had several broader impacts on STEM education access, educator capacity, and equity in STEM pathways.




Expanding STEM Access: By partnering with Sociedad Latina/BU and establishing new relationships with West End House and Bikes Not Bombs, we provided high-quality STEM and career programming to over 200 BIPOC middle school students who are underrepresented in STEM education and career pathways.




Building Educator Capacity: We provided professional development on the curriculum to educators at the three partnering community organizations, as well as those at Boston Public Schools. The educators were provided with administrative guides, lesson slides, demo videos, and access to our research team for additional support.




Promoting Student-Led Community Projects: Students applied their learning to create public service announcements and photo novellas addressing community issues and needs. This connected STEM concepts to civic engagement. For example, students developed a video PSA about COVID-19 vaccines, leveraging their understanding of network science to explain virus spread and the importance of vaccination. Disseminating Innovative Practices: Over the course of the 4-year project, we actively shared our curriculum, evaluation methods, and findings through numerous academic and professional channels. Sustainable Partnerships: Within Boston University, we formed a team that bridged the Wheelock College of Education and Human Development, the Department of Physics, and the Office of Government and Community Affairs. We also forged strong relationships between Boston University and two additional community organizations (West End House and Bikes Not Bombs) and strengthened our partnerships with Boston Public Schools to expand STEM pathways for youth beyond the project's duration.




Advancing Equity in STEM: By introducing students to Latinx STEM professionals and role models, we helped youth envision themselves in STEM careers, countering the underrepresentation of Latinx individuals in these fields. We also provided bilingual materials and support, ensuring that English language learners could fully engage with complex STEM concepts. Lastly, our focus on transferable skills like critical thinking, collaboration, and communication empowered students with competencies valuable across various career paths, expanding their options within and beyond traditional STEM fields.




In conclusion, this project developed an innovative, evidence-based approach to integrating network science and career development for middle school students. By connecting STEM concepts to students' identities, interests, and communities, we increased engagement and self-efficacy in STEM learning, aspiration, and career readiness. The curriculum and partnerships established provide a foundation for expanding access to STEM pathways for underrepresented youth and diversifying the STEM pipeline.
